title-group.article-title: Heterogeneity in Oligodendroglia: Is it Relevant to Mouse Models and Human Disease?

contrib-group.aff: Department of Pharmacology, Physiology & Neuroscience, New Jersey Medical School, Rutgers University, Newark, NJ, USA

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding Author: Dr. Teresa L. Wood, Department of Pharmacology, Physiology & Neuroscience, New Jersey Medical School and Cancer Center, Rutgers University, 205 South Orange Avenue, Newark, NJ 07101, USA, Terri.wood@rutgers.edu

fn.p: The authors declare no conflict of interest.

abstract.p: There are many lines of evidence indicating that OPC and oligodendrocyte populations in the CNS are heterogeneous based on their developmental origins as well as from morphological and molecular criteria. Whether these distinctions reflect functional heterogeneity is less clear and has been the subject of considerable debate. Recent findings particularly from knockout mouse models have provided new evidence for regional variations in myelination phenotypes, particularly between brain and spinal cord. These data raise the possibility that oligodendrocytes in these regions have different functional capacities and/or ability to compensate for loss of a specific gene. The goal of this review is to briefly revisit the evidence for oligodendrocyte heterogeneity and then to present data from transgenic and demyelinating mouse models suggesting functional heterogeneity in myelination, demyelination and remyelination in the CNS and finally, to discuss the implications of these findings for human diseases.
